repnme.cdata!:
Peru - Energy and Mining Technical
            Assistance Project (EMTAL)

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome is rated as satisfactory for
            preparation, appraisal, and implementation, both for Bank
            and Borrower. The key lessons are as follows: For technical
            assistance aimed at sector reforms to succeed, a) strong
            government support and consistency of project objectives
            with overall development requirements are critical; b)
            continuity of project direction and management needs to be
            ensured; c) project coordination and implementation units
            need to be carefully staffed, with emphasis on sectoral
            experience and networking skills; d) favorable macroeconomic
            conditions are important; and e) the use of United Nations
            Development Program or other local offices as disbursement
            agent helps to avoid bureaucratic delays in making project
            funds available. On the other hand, the project's
            shortcomings emphasize the need to a) avoid or at least
            limit the multiplicity of objectives and activities, design
            the project concept as firmly as feasible at appraisal, and
            ensure that loan covenants are enforceable; b) make
            appropriate arrangements for enhanced monitoring of complex
            projects, including adequate resources for supervision; and
            c) restrict labor-intensive and less effective types of
            contracting (e.g., use of individual consultants).

repnme.cdata!:
Peru - Energy and Mining Technical
            Assistance Loan (EMTAL) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the project is to
            assist the Government of Peru in the institutional
            development of the Ministry of Energy and Mines (MEM) and
            its related entities in order to ensure their adequate
            contribution to economic stabilization and structural reform
            in the energy and mining sectors, in particular to the
            privatization effort.  The project consists of:  (a) (i)
            consultancy services for carrying out studies which will
            provide recommendations for MEM's institutional
            development; and (ii) implementation of the recommendations
            of these studies; (b) training program for MEM and other
            relevant staff, in Peru and abroad; and (c) computer
            software and hardware, particularly to provide adequate
            statistical information to the market and to help MEM to
            develop its policies.  These services will assist MEM in:
            (i) completing the process of legal and regulatory reforms
            for the energy and mining sectors; (ii) strengthening its
            organizational units and procedures; (iii) increasing the
            professional capabilities of its staff; and (iv) developing
            specific guidelines for environmental protection in energy
            and mining projects.
